bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, September 23, 1894

div1.p: Laura Carter describes a boat trip with her father and brother, as well as a hurricane and the damage it caused.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, September 23, 1894
div1.opener:
I
Key West Quarentine
Florida Sep. 23rd 1894.
Dear Grandma.
div1.p:
A few days ago papa,
Henry and I went out in the
boat after sea-fans. He started
over in the direction of Hospital
Key, an island about two miles from
here. The way to get sea-fans
is to jump over board loosen
them with your feet and then
get them out of the water
any way that you can. We
went a long way, but the
water was too deep, so papa took
us to Hospital Key. We got
some very pretty sea-oats
for mama. There were no
shells there at all.

A few minuets after we had
started home, pape pointed to
a water spout! It was coming
towards us, and Henry and I
were very much scared. Papa
was only interested. It disappeared
in a little while. When we got
near the house papa saw some
sea-fans so he and I jumped
overboard after them. The water was
We got a good many
over Henry's head. Dr. Magnider
was going to Bird Key and up-
set again.

Had a hurrican last night-
Upset a pilot boat, blew
down a tent at Bird Key,
and blew paires of glass
out of two windows, We
do not know whether the
engineer who was in the
tent was hurt or not. As it
is blowing too hard for any
one to go to Bird Key.

I send you a piece of Tortugas
paper. Give my love to all
div1.closer:
Your loving grandaughter Laura. 24th 6. 11. P. M.
There has been a hurrican all
day. One could hardly stand
inside the fort. at 5. P. M. the
atmosphere was a vivid green.
It is blowing harder every
minuet. Every thing is torn to
pieces. Will state damages
in the morning... Laura.
241
25th 9-5, A. M.
The hurrican was dreadful
last night. It was not half
4
as bad yesterday as it is today.
The waves are dashing over the
breakwater and the moat is
dreadfully rough. The tin
has blown off the roof, two
chimneys are down, large
branches are torn off the cocoa
nut trees and others trees
are torn up by the roots.
the foam from the waves is
blown so hard by the wind
that is hurts dreadfully if
is Strikes you. We do not
know what has happened
at Bird Key as no small
boat could live in this
storm. So no one can get
there. Bricks have been coming
down the chimneys all night.
